clusters.title: Inside the Jaguar Land Rover cyberattack, which forced a shutdown of most systems and is likely to cost the company hundreds of millions of pounds (The Guardian)
clusters.neutral_headline: Inside the Jaguar Land Rover cyberattack, which forced a shutdown of most systems and is likely to cost the company hundreds of millions of pounds (The Guardian)

items.title: Inside the Jaguar Land Rover cyberattack, which forced a shutdown of most systems and is likely to cost the company hundreds of millions of pounds (The Guardian)
items.standfirst: The Guardian: Inside the Jaguar Land Rover cyberattack, which forced a shutdown of most systems and is likely to cost the company hundreds of millions of pounds — Being a carmaker where ‘everything is connected’ has left JLR unable to isolate its plants or functions, forcing a shutdown of most systems
items.content: The Guardian: Inside the Jaguar Land Rover cyberattack, which forced a shutdown of most systems and is likely to cost the company hundreds of millions of pounds — Being a carmaker where ‘everything is connected’ has left JLR unable to isolate its plants or functions, forcing a shutdown of most systems

items.title: Inside the Jaguar Land Rover hack: stalled smart factories, outsourced cybersecurity and supply chain woes
items.standfirst: Being a carmaker where ‘everything is connected’ has left JLR unable to isolate its plants or functions, forcing a shutdown of most systemsThe first external signs of the chaos about to hit JLR, Britain’s largest automotive employer, came on the quiet last Sunday of August. Managers at a factory in Halewood, Merseyside, told industry contacts there might have been a hack – although it was not clear then just how bad the situation was.That changed quickly on the Monday morning. JLR, the maker of the Jaguar and Land Rover brands, quickly shut down systems after realising the severity of the cyber-attack. Three weeks later, the carmaker is still incapacitated, unable to produce at any of its factories across the UK, Slovakia, Brazil and India (although a Chinese joint venture is thought to be operating). Continue reading...
items.content: Being a carmaker where ‘everything is connected’ has left JLR unable to isolate its plants or functions, forcing a shutdown of most systemsThe first external signs of the chaos about to hit JLR, Britain’s largest automotive employer, came on the quiet last Sunday of August. Managers at a factory in Halewood, Merseyside, told industry contacts there might have been a hack – although it was not clear then just how bad the situation was.That changed quickly on the Monday morning. JLR, the maker of the Jaguar and Land Rover brands, quickly shut down systems after realising the severity of the cyber-attack. Three weeks later, the carmaker is still incapacitated, unable to produce at any of its factories across the UK, Slovakia, Brazil and India (although a Chinese joint venture is thought to be operating). Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Jaguar Land Rover cyberattack forced a shutdown of most systems.
The attack is likely to cost the company hundreds of millions of pounds.
The carmaker is still incapacitated three weeks after the attack.
The attack has affected production at multiple factories.
The company's cybersecurity was outsourced.

clusters.title: Microsoft’s Entra ID vulnerabilities could have been catastrophic
clusters.neutral_headline: Microsoft’s Entra ID vulnerabilities could have been catastrophic

items.title: Microsoft’s Entra ID vulnerabilities could have been catastrophic
items.standfirst: They could've allowed attacker to gain access to virtually all Azure customer accounts.
items.content: As businesses around the world have shifted their digital infrastructure over the last decade from self-hosted servers to the cloud, they’ve benefitted from the standardized, built-in security features of major cloud providers like Microsoft. But with so much riding on these systems, there can be potentially disastrous consequences at a massive scale if something goes wrong. Case in point: Security researcher Dirk-jan Mollema recently stumbled upon a pair of vulnerabilities in Microsoft Azure’s identity and access management platform that could have been exploited for a potentially cataclysmic takeover of all Azure customer accounts. Known as Entra ID, the system stores each Azure cloud customer’s user identities, sign-in access controls, applications, and subscription management tools. Mollema has studied Entra ID security in depth and published multiple studies about weaknesses in the system, which was formerly known as Azure Active Directory. But while preparing to present at the Black Hat security conference in Las Vegas in July, Mollema discovered two vulnerabilities that he realized could be used to gain global administrator privileges—essentially god mode—and compromise every Entra ID directory, or what is known as a “tenant.” Mollema says that this would have exposed nearly every Entra ID tenant in the world other than, perhaps, government cloud infrastructure. “I was just staring at my screen. I was like, ‘No, this shouldn’t really happen,’” says Mollema, who runs the Dutch cybersecurity company Outsider Security and specializes in cloud security. “It was quite bad. As bad as it gets, I would say.”Read full article Comments

ai_summary: Microsoft's Entra ID vulnerabilities could have been catastrophic.
The vulnerabilities could have allowed attackers to access Azure accounts.
The article does not specify the exact nature of the vulnerabilities.
The article focuses on the potential impact of the vulnerabilities.
The article does not specify the number of affected accounts.

clusters.title: You’ll enjoy the Specialized Turbo Vado SL 2 6.0 Carbon even without assist
clusters.neutral_headline: You’ll enjoy the Specialized Turbo Vado SL 2 6.0 Carbon even without assist

items.title: You’ll enjoy the Specialized Turbo Vado SL 2 6.0 Carbon even without assist
items.standfirst: It's an investment, certainly of money, but also in long, fast rides.
items.content: Two things about the Specialized Turbo Vado SL 2 6.0 Carbon are hard to fathom: One is how light and lithe it feels as an e-bike, even with the battery off; the other is how hard it is to recite its full name when other riders ask you about the bike at stop lights and pit stops. I’ve tested about a half-dozen e-bikes for Ars Technica. Each test period has included a ride with my regular group for about 30 miles. Nobody else in my group rides electric, so I try riding with no assist, at least part of the way. Usually I give up after a mile or two, realizing that most e-bikes are not designed for unpowered rides. On the Carbon (as I’ll call it for the rest of this review), you can ride without power. At 35 pounds, it’s no gram-conscious road bike, but it feels lighter than that number implies. My daily ride is an aluminum-framed model with an internal geared hub that weighs about the same, so I might be a soft target. But it’s a remarkable thing to ride an e-bike that starts with a good unpowered ride and lets you build on that with power.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: The Specialized Turbo Vado SL 2 6.0 Carbon is an investment.
The investment is in money and in long, fast rides.
The article focuses on the experience of riding the bike.
The article does not specify the price of the bike.
The article does not specify the type of assist the bike offers.

clusters.title: Starship will soon fly over towns and cities, but will dodge the biggest ones
clusters.neutral_headline: Starship to fly over Florida and Mexico on launches

items.title: Starship will soon fly over towns and cities, but will dodge the biggest ones
items.standfirst: Starship's next chapter will involve launching over Florida and returning over Mexico.
items.content: Some time soon, perhaps next year, SpaceX will attempt to fly one of its enormous Starship rockets from low-Earth orbit back to its launch pad in South Texas. A successful return and catch at the launch tower would demonstrate a key capability underpinning Elon Musk's hopes for a fully reusable rocket. In order for this to happen, SpaceX must overcome the tyranny of geography. Unlike launches over the open ocean from Cape Canaveral, Florida, rockets departing from South Texas must follow a narrow corridor to steer clear of downrange land masses. All 10 of the rocket's test flights so far have launched from Texas toward splashdowns in the Indian or Pacific Oceans. On these trajectories, the rocket never completes a full orbit around the Earth, but instead flies an arcing path through space before gravity pulls it back into the atmosphere.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: Starship's next phase involves launches over Florida and returns over Mexico.
The launches will avoid flying over the largest cities in the United States.
The exact flight paths and specific locations are still being finalized.
SpaceX is working with regulatory agencies to secure necessary approvals.
This marks a significant step in Starship's development and testing.

clusters.title: In a win for science, NASA told to use House budget as shutdown looms
clusters.neutral_headline: NASA budget cuts are less severe than initially proposed

items.title: In a win for science, NASA told to use House budget as shutdown looms
items.standfirst: The House budget still cuts science at NASA, but not as deeply as the White House sought.
items.content: The situation with the fiscal year 2026 budget for the United States is, to put it politely, kind of a mess. The White House proposed a budget earlier this year with significant cuts for a number of agencies, including NASA. In the months since then, through the appropriations process, both the House and Senate have proposed their own budget templates. However, Congress has not passed a final budget, and the new fiscal year begins on October 1. As a result of political wrangling over whether to pass a "continuing resolution" to fund the government before a final budget is passed, a government shutdown appears to be increasingly likely.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: The House budget includes cuts to NASA's science programs.
These cuts are less drastic than those proposed by the White House.
The final budget allocation will determine the extent of the impact.
Funding for specific projects and missions remains uncertain.
The budget process is ongoing and subject to further revisions.

clusters.title: After a very slow start, Europe’s reusable rocket program shows signs of life
clusters.neutral_headline: Europe's reusable rocket program shows slow progress

items.title: After a very slow start, Europe’s reusable rocket program shows signs of life
items.standfirst: Although Themis is making progress, the program is several years behind schedule.
items.content: No one could accuse the European Space Agency and its various contractors of moving swiftly when it comes to the development of reusable rockets. However, it appears that Europe is finally making some credible progress. This week, the France-based ArianeGroup aerospace company announced that it had completed the integration of the Themis vehicle, a prototype rocket that will test various landing technologies, on a launch pad in Sweden. Low-altitude hop tests, a precursor for developing a rocket's first stage that can vertically land after an orbital launch, could start late this year or early next. "This milestone marks the beginning of the 'combined tests,' during which the interface between Themis and the launch pad's mechanical, electrical, and fluid systems will be thoroughly trialed, with the aim of completing a test under cryogenic conditions," the company said.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: Themis, Europe's reusable rocket program, is making progress.
The program is currently several years behind its original schedule.
Delays are attributed to technical challenges and funding issues.
The program aims to develop a reusable first-stage rocket.
Success is crucial for Europe's space launch capabilities.

clusters.title: Microsoft raises Xbox console prices for the second time this year
clusters.neutral_headline: Microsoft increases Xbox console prices for the second time

items.title: Microsoft raises Xbox console prices for the second time this year
items.standfirst: Asking prices for some models are up 33 percent in less than a year.
items.content: Less than a month ago, we looked at how current game console prices were historically high due to price increases from all three major console makers. Today, that analysis is already a bit out of date, as Microsoft has announced its second set of Xbox price increases this year in the US. The new Xbox price hikes, which will go into effect on October 3, or roughly five months after the last set of Xbox price hikes, are as follows: Xbox Series S 512GB: $400 (up from $380 in May / launched at $300 in 2020) Xbox Series S 1TB: $450 (up from $430 in May / launched at $350 in 2023) Xbox Series X Digital: $600 (from $550 in May / launched at $450 in 2024) Xbox Series X: $650 (up from $600 in May / launched at $500 in 2020) Xbox Series X 2TB Galaxy Special Edition: $800 (up from $730 in May / launched at $600 in 2024) In an Xbox Support post, Microsoft cited the now-standard "changes in the macroeconomic environment" for the decision to move pricing yet again. "We understand that these changes are challenging, and they were made with careful consideration," the company wrote. "Looking ahead, we continue to focus on offering more ways to play more games across any screen and providing value for Xbox players.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: Microsoft has raised Xbox console prices again this year.
Some models have increased in price by up to 33 percent.
The price increases affect various Xbox console models.
The company cites economic factors as the reason for the change.
This is the second price increase within a year for some consoles.

clusters.title: Bonkers CDC vaccine meeting ends with vote to keep COVID shot access
clusters.neutral_headline: CDC votes to maintain access to COVID shots

items.title: Bonkers CDC vaccine meeting ends with vote to keep COVID shot access
items.standfirst: A push to require prescriptions for every COVID shot failed in a split vote.
items.content: A two-day federal vaccine advisory meeting crammed with chaos, confusion, inept debate, bizarre comments, and a hot mic catching someone saying "you're an idiot," ended with an unexpected twist: The advisors unanimously voted—possibly unintentionally—to maintain broad access to COVID-19 vaccines. In the 12–0 vote, the committee of advisors selected by anti-vaccine activist Robert F. Kennedy Jr. adopted a recommendation for adults 65 and older and people aged 6 months to 64 years to get a COVID-19 vaccine based on shared clinical decision-making. After this story was published, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention adopted the recommendation, which will broadly maintain requirements that federal and private health insurance plans cover COVID-19 vaccines at no cost. While the shared clinical decision-making is a new requirement, the CDC noted in adopting the recommendation that such decision making can be done in consultation with providers, "including physicians, nurses, and pharmacists". Most people receive COVID-19 vaccines from their local pharmacists. Earlier this year, the FDA limited the approvals of this year's shots, which have previously been available to anyone 6 months of age or older. The FDA's new restriction limits them to adults aged 65 and up and for people between the ages of 6 months and 64 years who have an underlying medical condition that puts them at high risk of severe COVID-19.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: A CDC meeting concluded with a vote to keep COVID shot access.
A proposal to require prescriptions for shots was rejected.
The vote was split among the members of the committee.
The decision impacts access to COVID-19 vaccinations.
The meeting addressed ongoing vaccine recommendations.

clusters.title: Oklahoma’s big “TV nudes” scandal was… a Jackie Chan movie on a Samsung streaming service
clusters.neutral_headline: Oklahoma TV nudes scandal involved a Jackie Chan movie

items.title: Oklahoma’s big “TV nudes” scandal was… a Jackie Chan movie on a Samsung streaming service
items.content: Since July, the state of Oklahoma has been consumed by important investigative questions, including: Why did naked women appear on a state-owned TV set during an official Board of Education meeting? Was someone in the room inadvertently streaming pornography from a personal device to the TV? Will anyone be prosecuted for what happened? Were the board members who complained about the video directed by the governor to "lie about me," as the state's pugnacious, hard-right Superintendent of Education asked? Why was a "chiropractic table" involved in the scene? And why did the video feature, as one board member noted, a retro vibe and "a guy with a white hat, kind of a Gilligan-type hat"? We now have answers to all of those questions. After a lengthy investigation by the Oklahoma County Sheriff's Office and the State Bureau of Investigation, and then a lengthy consideration of their reports, the Oklahoma County District Attorney this week announced that "there is insufficient evidence to file criminal charges."Read full article Comments

ai_summary: An Oklahoma "TV nudes" scandal involved a Jackie Chan movie.
The movie was streamed on a Samsung streaming service.
The incident highlights potential privacy concerns with smart TVs.
The specific details of the incident are still emerging.
The scandal has raised questions about content security.

clusters.title: Chimps consume alcohol equivalent of nearly 2 drinks a day
clusters.neutral_headline: Chimps consume alcohol equivalent of nearly two drinks daily

items.title: Chimps consume alcohol equivalent of nearly 2 drinks a day
items.standfirst: It's the latest evidence in support of Robert Dudley's controversial "drunk monkey" hypothesis.
items.content: In 2014, University of California, Berkeley biologist Robert Dudley wrote a book called The Drunken Monkey: Why We Drink and Abuse Alcohol. His controversial "drunken monkey hypothesis" proposed that the human attraction to alcohol goes back about 18 million years, to the origin of the great apes, and that social communication and sharing food evolved to better identify the presence of fruit from a distance. At the time, skeptical scientists insisted that this was unlikely because chimpanzees and other primates just don't eat fermented fruit or nectar. But reports of primates doing just that have grown over the ensuing two decades. Dudley co-authored a new paper published in the journal Science Advances reporting the first measurements of the ethanol content of fruits favored by chimps in Ivory Coast and Uganda, finding that the chimps are consuming 14 grams of alcohol every day, the equivalent of a standard alcoholic drink in the US. After adjusting for the chimps' lower body mass, the authors concluded the chimps are consuming nearly two drinks per day. Earlier this year, we reported that researchers had caught wild chimpanzees on camera engaging in what appears to be sharing fermented African breadfruit with measurable alcoholic content. That observational data was the first evidence of the sharing of alcoholic foods among nonhuman great apes in the wild. They recorded 10 instances of selective fruit sharing among 17 chimps, with the animals exhibiting a marked preference for riper fruit. Between April and July 2022, the authors measured the alcohol content of the fruit with a handy portable breathalyzer and found almost all of the fallen fruit (90 percent) contained some ethanol, with the ripest containing the highest levels—the equivalent of 0.61 percent ABV (alcohol by volume).Read full article Comments

ai_summary: Chimpanzees consume alcohol equivalent to almost two drinks daily.
This supports the "drunk monkey" hypothesis by Robert Dudley.
The study provides further evidence of alcohol consumption.
The research explores the evolutionary origins of alcohol preference.
The findings contribute to understanding primate behavior.

clusters.title: Two of the Kremlin’s most active hack groups are collaborating, ESET says
clusters.neutral_headline: Russian hack groups Turla and Gamaredon are collaborating

items.title: Two of the Kremlin’s most active hack groups are collaborating, ESET says
items.standfirst: Turla is getting a helping hand from Gamaredon. Both are units of Russia's FSB.
items.content: Two of the Kremlin’s most active hacking units recently were spotted collaborating in malware attacks that compromise high-value devices located in Ukraine, security researchers said Friday. One of the groups is Turla, which is easily one of the world’s most sophisticated advanced persistent threats (well-organized and well-funded hacking groups, many backed by nation states, that target specific adversaries for years at a time). Researchers from multiple security firms largely agree that Turla was behind breaches of the US Department of Defense in 2008, and more recently, the German Foreign Office and France's military. The group has also been known for unleashing stealthy Linux malware and using satellite-based Internet links to maintain the stealth of its operations. The group conducts narrowly targeted attacks on high-value targets and keeps a low profile. Gamaredon, meanwhile, is a separate APT known for conducting much wider-scale operations, often targeting organizations in Ukraine. Whereas Turla takes pains to fly under the radar, Gamaredon doesn’t seem to care about being detected and linked to the Russian government. Its malware generally aims to collect as much information from targets as possible over a short period of time. Both Turla and Gamaredon are widely assessed to be units of Russia’s Russian Federal Security Service (FSB), the country’s chief security agency and successor of the Soviet Union’s KGB.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: Two Russian hacking groups are collaborating, according to ESET.
Turla is receiving assistance from Gamaredon in their operations.
Both groups are units of Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB).
The collaboration increases the sophistication of attacks.
The groups are known for cyber espionage and attacks.
